If not, what job was he actually performing?
What is the name of the officer concerned?
Is it suggested that the aircraft concerned was actually flying below 500 feet contrary to regulations at any time; if so, what evidence is there of this?

Is it suggested that "during the lapse of time" between the original observations by the departmental officer, and the obtaining of actual evidence of the height of the aircraft, that the actual height of the aircraft was increased?
Why did the department's regional office in Brisbane convey an apology to the employers of the captain of this aircraft?
Why was the captain's licence suspended?
What was the evidence that the aircraft was "apparently flown at a relatively low height"?
If there is any evidence, what was the height?
Why was the captain required to undergo a proficiency test?
When did the captain first suffer the illness diagnosed as an anxiety state?
Was there any evidence that he was subject to an illness of that kind before that date?
What evidence is there that his illness was not specifically related to his profession as a pilot?
What was the expert medical evidence in this matter, and by whom was it tendered?
When was a question first asked in Parliament on this matter?
When was action first taken which led to the removal of restrictions on the captain's licence?
Was there any connexion between these events?

By whom were the decisions made to suspend the captain's licence, to require him to undergo a proficiency test, to require him to fly under supervision, to declare him unfit to fly and to remove restrictions upon his licence?
What losses in pay and benefits has the captain suffered as a result of these events?
Is it a fact that he has suffered these losses even though it is now admitted that he was in no way at fault on 31st March, 1963?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: The officer concerned, Mr. O. de V. O'Reilly is employed as an Inspector of Air Safety in the Queensland region of the Department of Civil Aviation. On 31st March, 1963, he was a passenger to Charleville on a Trans-Australia Airlines aircraft commanded by Captain H. S. Yorston. Mr. O'Reilly was travelling for the purpose of investigating an aircraft accident which occurred in the Charleville area on the previous day. In the performance of his duties as an Inspector of Air Safety Mr. O'Reilly is expected at all times to take note of any potentially unsafe situation arid to take investigatory or notification action appropriate to that situation.
See answer to question 1.
See answer to question 1.

In the opinion of Mr. O'Reilly, who is considered to be a competent judge of height above ground, the aircraft was at one period operating at less than 500 ft. above the ground. This opinion by Mr O'Reilly was supported by another departmental officer who was a passenger on the same aircraft. It was considered that the aircraft was flown at a height quite inappropriate to a regular transport operation having regard to the fact that it was not engaged in take-off or landing operations, was en route to its destination, and that it was fully equipped for instrument flight.
As I indicated in my answer given yesterday to a similar question, the evidence in this case does suggest that during this lapse of time the actual height of the aircraft had been increased.

A full answer has already been given to this question. The apology was related only to the aspect of Mr. O'Reilly's entry to the cockpit without observance of the normal practised courtesy of obtaining an invitation to do so. I again stress that Mr. O'Reilly held a valid authority to enter the cockpit and that he not unreasonably considered that the particular circumstances warranted entry without awaiting invitation.
The Air Navigation Regulations provide that where the Director-General has reason to suspect -

item.label: (a)
item.para: that the holder of the licence or certificate has contravened, or failed to apply with, a provision or the act or regulations including those regulations as enforced by virtue of a law of a State, or

item.label: (b)
item.para: that the holder of the licence or certificate fails to satisfy or to continue to satisfy, any requirements prescribed by, or specified under those regulations in relation to the obtaining or holding of such a licence or certificate; or

item.label: (c)
item.para: that the holder of the licence orcertificate has failed in his duty with respect to any matter affecting the safe or efficient navigation or operation of an aircraft; or

item.label: (d)
item.para: that the holder of the licence or certificate is not a fit and proper person to have the responsibilities and to exercise and perform the functions and duties of a holder of such a licence or certificate ... he may suspend the licence of the pilot concerned pending a detailed investigation. Captain Yorston's licence was suspended under these provisions.
I refer to my reply to question 4.

Mr. O'Reilly's action was promoted by his belief that the aircraft was being flown at a height of only 300-350 feet above the ground. The estimate of height made during the same period by the other officer accompanying Mr. O'Reilly was 250-300 feet.

The Air Navigation Regulations provide that whenever the Director-General considers it necessary in the interests of the safety of air navigation for a pilot to demonstrate his continued proficiency the Director-General may require him to undergo an examination. The evidence obtained during investigation of this incident revealed a possible doubt as to the proficiency of Captain Yorston under instrument flying conditions. This doubt could be resolved only by requiring Captain Yorston to undergo a flight test.
So far as is known Captain Yorston first complained of the symptoms, diagnosed as an anxiety state, on 16th May, 1963.
There is no evidence in Civil Aviation medical records that he was subject to an illness of that kind before that date.

The symptoms associated with this illness were those typically occurring in an anxiety state arising from any cause, mainly sleeplessness. In addition the symptoms did not come on until a number of weeks after the incident in the air which led to the suspension of his licence.
The expert medical evidence was in the form of two reports from Dr. Vincent Youngman of 97 Wickham-terrace, Brisbane, a recognized specialist psychiatrist.
On 10th October, 1963.

Captain Yorston was notified on 9th May, 1963, of the action which would be necessary on his part to bring about the removal of restrictions on his licence. The time taken to meet these requirements was then largely in his hands, but it was subsequently affected by the consideration of his medical fitness.

There obviously could have been no connexion between the events covered by questions 15 and 16. It is purely circumstantial that Captain Yorston was declared to be medically fit to undergo the necessary flight tests about the time that this matter was first raised in Parliament.
By the Director-General of Civil Aviation acting under the powers conferred on him by the Air Navigation Act and Regulations.

Trans-Australia Airlines advised that the pilot suffered no loss of pay while under suspension from flying duties. He was on sick leave for 129 days, 126 days of which were on full pay and three days on half pay.
See answer to question 19. The Department of Civil Aviation has not, at any time, admitted that Captain Yorston was in no way at fault on 31st March, 1963.

talk.start.para: - On 26th February, the honorable member for Kingston (Mr. Galvin) asked me whether I would consider conferring with the Commonwealth Minister for Health and the Postmaster-General on the possibility of conducting a nation-wide campaign on the dangers of cigarette smoking. In reply I mentioned that the Minister for Health had been looking at this matter and that I was looking forward to his advising me of the result of his investigation. The Minister for Health has now informed me that at a meeting in February, the Ministers of Health of the Commonwealth and the States were unanimous that the best results would be obtained by pursuing a policy of educating young people and it was decided to launch a campaign to publicize the health hazards of smoking. It was agreed that unilateral action would not be as effective as concerted action by the Commonwealth and the States. A health education conference will be held this month to discuss the ways and means by which a uniform campaign can be developed and conducted.
